revisions.rev:
{{good article}}{{Infobox album | Name = Most Wanted | Type = compilation | Artist = [[Hilary Duff]] | Cover = Hilary Duff Most Wanted.jpg | Alt = The portrait of a blonde young woman sitting in front of a white background. She is sitting, looking into the camera. She is wearing a gray colored, full-sleeved top. To the bottom of the picture, the words "HILARY DUFF" and "MOST WANTED" are printed in black block letters. | Border = yes | Released = {{Start date|2005|08|10}} | Recorded = 2003â05 | Genre = [[Dance-pop]], [[teen pop]], [[bubblegum pop]]{{cite journal|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=KekDAAAAMBAJ|title=Reviews|journal=GameAxis Unwired|publisher=[[Singapore Press Holdings|SPH Magazines]]|issue=26|month=October|year=2005|issn=0219-872X|location=Singapore|page=50|accessdate=2011-10-17}} | Length = {{Duration|m=48|s=58}} | Label = [[Hollywood Records|Hollywood]] | Producer = [[Chico Bennett]], [[Meredith Brooks]], Julian Bunetta, [[Andreas Carlsson]], [[Chris Cox (DJ)|Chris Cox]], [[Kevin De Clue]], [[Dead Executives]], [[Desmond Child]], [[Haylie Duff]], Hilary Duff (exec.), [[Matthew Gerrard]], [[Charlie Midnight]], [[The Matrix (production team)|The Matrix]], Andre Recke (also exec.), [[John Shanks]], Ty Stevens, [[Greg Wells]], Denny Weston, Jr. | Last album = ''[[Hilary Duff (album)|Hilary Duff]]''
(2004) | This album = '''''Most Wanted'''''
(2005) | Next album = ''[[4ever Hilary Duff]]''
(2006) | Misc = {{Singles | Name = Most Wanted | Type = compilation | Single 1 = [[Wake Up (Hilary Duff song)|Wake Up]] | Single 1 date = {{Start date|2005|07|12}} | Single 2 = [[Beat of My Heart]] | Single 2 date = {{Start date|2005|12|12}} | Single 3 = [[Fly (Hilary Duff song)|Fly]] | Single 3 date = {{Start date|2006|03|13}} }}}} '''''Most Wanted''''' is the first compilation album by American recording artist [[Hilary Duff]]. Released on August 10, 2005, through [[Hollywood Records]], the album comprises ten previously released tracks (three of which are in a remixed form), and three new recordings: "[[Wake Up (Hilary Duff song)|Wake Up]]", "[[Beat of My Heart]]", and "Break My Heart". A deluxe edition of the album, subtitled ''The Collector's Signature Edition'', was also released, containing additional remixes and another new recording "Supergirl". At first, Duff was concerned about the reaction of fans to the new songs, since they carry a "totally different sound" and are more dance-oriented than her previous music. Following its release, ''Most Wanted'' received mostly negative reviews from critics, who deemed the release as premature, stating that Duff did not have enough material to warrant a compilation. However, the Executives produced tracks received favorable comments, who wrote that they stood out from the rest of the album. In the United States, the album debuted atop the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] chart, becoming Duff's second number one album there. It was later certified Platinum by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). Elsewhere, it debuted at number one in Canada, and reached the top ten in Australia, Ireland, Italy, Japan and New Zealand. Two singles were released from the album. The lead single, "Wake Up", was released in August 2005, and peaked within the top ten in countries including Italy, Norway and the United Kingdom. In the United States, the song reached number 29 and was certified Gold by the RIAA. The accompanying [[music video]] features Duff portraying styles from cities over the world like [[London]] and [[Tokyo]]. The second single, "Beat of My Heart", peaked in the top 20 in countries such as Australia, Italy and Spain. Duff also embarked on a worldwide tour to support the album. Entitled the [[Hilary Duff concert tours#Still Most Wanted Tour|Still Most Wanted Tour]], the tour ran from July 2005 through September 2006. == Background and development == On May 20, 2005, [[MTV News]] reported that Hilary Duff would be releasing a new album in August, comprising previously released tracks and four new recordings.{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Chris|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1502662/hilary-duff-lines-up-32-dates.jhtml|title=Hilary Duff Lines Up 32 Summer Dates|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks (Viacom)|date=2005-05-20|accessdate=2011-09-02}} It was also announced that preceding the album's release, Duff would begin a 32-date summer concert tour in support of the album. Four days later, on May 24, the album's title was revealed to be ''Most Wanted'', and the album's release date was announced to be August 16, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1502881/britney-freaks-on-next-episode-chaotic.jhtml|title=For the Record: Quick News on Britney Spears, Hilary Duff, Mariah Carey, Nas, Nine Inch Nails, Bam Margera & More|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks (Viacom) |date=2005-05-24|accessdate=2011-09-02}} The following month, in an interview with MTV News, Duff said that she had been working with brothers [[Joel Madden|Joel]] and [[Benji Madden]], of the American rock band [[Good Charlotte]], and [[Jason "Jay E" Epperson|Jason Epperson]] (together known under the production name the [[Dead Executives]]) to write and produce new songs for the compilation. She said that " ... they're three of my favorite songs I've ever done. ... It was really fun being in the studio with them." Described by Duff as the first time when "all the responsibility was on [her]", she went into the recording studio without the guidance of her record label or management.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1510003/hilary-worried-about-madden-music.jhtml|title=Hilary Says She Worried About Fan Reaction to Madden-Produced Music|last=Tecson |first=Brandee J.|date=2005-09-20|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks (Viacom)|accessdate=2011-09-02}} According to Duff, she did not tell anyone at her record label that she was working with the Dead Executives.{{cite web|last=Tecson|first=Brandee J.|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1505821/hilary-good-charlotte-duet-dont-think-so.jhtml|title=Hilary Draws the Line at Collaborating with Good Charlotte|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks (Viacom)|date=2005-07-18|accessdate=2011-09-02}} Joel, whom Duff had been dating at the time, was aware that she needed new material for a compilation album, and knew that she wanted a "totally different sound". Together, the Dead Executives went into the recording studio and worked on new music for Duff, before bringing her into the studio to collectively work on them. {{Quote box|width=30%|align=right|quote=" ... The first one we're going to release ['Wake Up'] is very dancey, kind of pop â not '80s, but kind of with that in it, so it's very fun. Another ['Beat of My Heart'] is more techno, like [[DJ Sammy]] almost, and the third one ['Break My Heart'] is a pop-punk song, more like [[[Good Charlotte]]'s] music." |source=âDuff on the new songs recorded for the album{{cite web|last=Tecson|first=Brandee J.|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1503561/hilary-duff-teams-up-with-maddens-new-lp.jhtml |title=Cheaper by the Duo? Hilary Duff Teams Up With Madden Brothers for New LP|publisher=[[MTV News]]. [[MTV Networks]] ([[Viacom]])|date=2005-06-06 |accessdate=2011-09-02}}}} Duff described working with them as pleasant, and the music as a new milestone in her career, stating that working with "people you're close with makes a world of difference when you're recording and being creative." At the same time, Duff was also nervous about how her fans would react to the new music. Duff recorded four tracks for the album,{{cite web|url=http://login.vnuemedia.com/bbbiz/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000957087 |title=Duff's 'Most Wanted' to Boast New Songs|last=A. Jeckell|first=Barry|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Nielsen Company|Nielsen Business Media, Inc]]|date=2005-06-14 |accessdate=2011-09-02}} three of which appear on the standard edition of the albumâ"Wake Up", "Beat of My Heart" and "Break My Heart"â while the fourth appears only on the deluxe edition: "Supergirl". The song was penned by Duff alongside [[Kara DioGuardi]] and [[Greg Wells]].{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/title.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&keyID=7710116&ShowNbr=0&ShowSeqNbr=0&querytype=WorkID|title=Supergirl (Legal Title) BMI Work #7710116|publisher =[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]|accessdate=2011-10-17}} The track listing for ''Most Wanted'' was revealed on July 12, 2005,{{cite web|url=http://login.vnuemedia.com/bbbiz/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1000977717 |title=Duff Finalizes Most wanted Track List|last=A. Jeckell|first=Barry|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|date=2005-07-12 |accessdate=2011-09-02}} and the album was released on August 16, 2005 in the United States and Canada. The Japanese standard edition of the album features the same track listing as ''The Collector's Signature Edition'', with additional remixes of "Wake Up" by DJ Kaya, and was released on August 10, 2005.{{cite web|last=Thomas Erlewine|first=Stephen|authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|url=http://allmusic.com/album/most-wanted-japan-bonus-tracks-r970228|title=Most Wanted [Japan Bonus Track] â Hilary Duff |publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]]|accessdate=2011-10-17}} Another version with a bonus DVD including music videos to selected songs and "making of" clips was also released in the same region.{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.co.jp/dp/B0009VEC0E/|title=ã¢ã¼ã¹ãã»ã¦ã©ã³ããã(ååéå®ç¤): ãã©ãªã¼ã»ãã: é³æ¥½|publisher=Amazon.co.jp|language=Japanese|accessdate=2011-09-10}} In the US, the iTunes digital version includes an interview with Duff. A deluxe edition of the album, subtitled ''The Collector's Signature Edition'', was also released, containing an acoustic version of "Who's That Girl?", an alternate version of "Jericho" and a remix of "Party Up" along with "Supergirl". The pressing features a different album art and was packed with four autographed photo cards and a [[wristband]].{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1507660/new-releases-hilary-duff-click-five-311.jhtml|title=New Releases: Hilary Duff, Click Five, Rick James, 311, Taproot, Idlewild, Cowboy Junkies|last=Orzeck|first=Kurt|publisher=[[MTV]]. MTV Networks (Viacom)|date=2005-08-15|accessdate=2011-10-17}} ''Most Wanted'' also contains 10 previously released tracks from ''[[Metamorphosis (Hilary Duff album)|Metamorphosis]]'' (2003) and ''[[Hilary Duff (album)|Hilary Duff]]'' (2004), as well as songs from soundtracks of Duff's films: ''[[The Lizzie McGuire Movie]]'' (2003) and ''[[A Cinderella Story]]'' (2004), three of whichâ"[[Come Clean (Hilary Duff song)|Come Clean]]", "Rock This World" and "[[Why Not (song)|Why Not]]"âare in a remixed form. ==New songs and remixes== {{Listen | filename = Beat of My Heart.ogg | title = "Beat of My Heart" | description = A 19-second sample of "Beat of My Heart", a [[bubblegum pop]] song, where Duff repeats the phrase 'beat of my heart'. Critics deemed the song as repetitive and childish. | filename2 = Break My Heart (Hilary Duff).ogg | title2 = "Break My Heart" | description2 = A 20-second sample of "Break My Heart". The song features a heavy dance tone and was compared to the works by [[Good Charlotte]]. | format = [[Ogg]] }} "Wake Up", the opening track, is a mid-tempo{{cite web|first1=John|last1=Feldmann|first2=Benji|last2=Madden|first3=Joel|last3=Madden|first4=Hilary|first4=Duff|title=Digital Sheet Music – Hilary Duff – Wake Up|work=''Musicnotes.com''|publisher=[[EMI|EMI Music Publishing]]|year=2005}} number backed by [[dance music|dance]], [[pop music|pop]] and [[electronic music|electronic]] beats,{{cite web|url=http://top40.about.com/od/singles/gr/wakeuphduff.htm|title=Wake Up â Hilary Duff|last=Lamb|first=Bill|publisher=About.com. [[The New York Times Company]]|accessdate=2009-11-02}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/01/arts/music/01duff.html|title=These Kids Today: A Bit Pop, a Bit Punk|last=Sanneh|first=Kelefa|work=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=2005-09-01|accessdate=2011-10-09}} and has "a more mature [[Electropop|pop-techno]] sound" than Duff's previous work. Its instrumentation includes a [[guitar]], [[Bass guitar|bass]] and [[drum]]s. Kelefa Anneth of ''[[The New York Times]]'' noted that the song contains musical influences of [[The Go-Go's]]. The lyrics of the song speak about having fun. Duff initially sings about the consequences of her fame and how people think they know "everything about [me]" ("There's people talking / They talk about me / They know my name / They think they know everything / But they don't know anything about me"). As the chorus draws near, the song takes on a "party anthem" approach, where Duff discusses the "struggle" for joy and self-confidence: "I know I make mistakes / I'm living life day to day / It's never really easy but it's OK..." According to Duff, the song "makes you want to forget about all the pressure of dealing with your boss, or your teacher, or your mom, or [whoever]," and lyrically discusses "getting out and not forgetting to have some fun." Duff has also said the song also "talks about being in all [my] favorite places in the world, which is Tokyo and Paris and London and New York."2007. "At Home with Hilary Duff" featurette on ''[[Dignity (album)|Dignity]]'' deluxe edition DVD. [[Hollywood Records]]: Canada (D000033800). "Beat of My Heart", the third track on the album, is inspired by the [[New Wave music|new wave]] genre. The song also draws influences from the [[bubblegum pop]] and dance genres.{{cite news|url=http://articles.boston.com/2007-09-01/news/29227047_1_hilary-duff-malibu-barbie-pop|title=Duff, and her tunes, are all dolled up|last=Anderman|first=Joan|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=2007-09-01|accessdate=2011-10-09}}{{cite news|first=Rick|last=Massimo|title=Hilary Duff delivers the stuff of teen-girl dreams|work=[[The Providence Journal]]|publisher=[[A. H. Belo|A. H. Belo Corporation]]|date=2005-07-25|accessdate=2011-10-09}} It carries a "soft electronic pop" sound and has the [[heart sounds|heart beat sound]] as its base.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/newsid_4930000/newsid_4938900/4938986.stm |title=Single Review: Hilary Duff â Beat of My Heart|publisher=[[CBBC|CBBC News]]. [[British Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=2011-09-02}} According to [[Chuck Taylor (writer and editor)|Chuck Taylor]] of ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine, the word 'beat of my heart' is repeated forty-four times in the song.{{cite journal|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=hhMEAAAAMBAJ|title=Reviews: Singles|last=Taylor|first=Chuck|authorlink=Chuck Taylor (writer and editor)|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|volume=117|issue=48|page=65|issn=0006-2510|date=2005-11-26|accessdate=2011-10-17}} The next new track and the ninth track on the album, "Break My Heart" is another dance-inspired number incorporating [[pop punk]] elements, and was described as a "highly produced [[four-on-the-floor]] rocker." The song interpolates "slick and clean 'punk' guitars and a chugging rhythm". "Break My Heart" leans more towards the rock genre and was compared to the works of [[Good Charlotte]]. The lyrics describe the feelings faced by the protagonist, following her heartbreak. Bill Lamb of [[About.com]] observed that "Beat of My Heart" and "Break My Heart" were "cookie cutter copies" of [[Avril Lavigne]]'s "[[Sk8er Boi]]" (2002). "Come Clean", "Why Not" and "Rock This World" are featured as club remixes in ''Most Wanted''. According to Spence D. of [[IGN]], "Come Clean", remixed by [[Chris Cox (DJ)|Chris Cox]] exhibits elements of [[house music]], while "Rock This World" displays "[[Kid Rock]]-meets-[[Aerosmith]] rock blitz". He classified the remix of "Why Not" as a "hyperkinetic pop" sped-up to a "level of sugar high bounce". Another remix, of the [[Diane Warren]]-penned "I Am", is included as a [[hidden track]], with added [[synth]]s to give it a [[1980s in music|'80s]] [[Indie music|indie]] feel. The version of "Girl Can Rock" featured on the album, according to Anthony Miccio of ''[[Baltimore City Paper]]'' has a [[chord progression]] similar to the song "[[Cherry Pie (Warrant song)|Cherry Pie]]" by American band [[Warrant (American band)|Warrant]]. The song displays elements of [[country music]] and the lyrics are a "[[statement of purpose]]". Duff sings the chorus, backed by a [[guitar]]: "It ain't no shock/ The girl can rock". == Critical reception == {{Album reviews | rev1 = [[About.com]] | rev1score = {{Rating|4|5}}{{cite web|url=http://top40.about.com/od/albums/fr/mostwantedduff.htm|title=Most Wanted â Hilary Duff|last=Lamb|first=Bill|publisher=About.com. The New York Times Company|accessdate=2009-11-02}} | rev2 = [[Allmusic]] | rev2score = {{Rating|3|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/r782736|title=Most Wanted â Hilary Duff > Overview|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2009-11-02}} | rev3 = ''[[Baltimore City Paper]]'' | rev3Score = (unfavorable){{cite news|url=http://www2.citypaper.com/music/review.asp?rid=9581|title=Hilary Duff / Most Wanted â Record Review |work=[[Baltimore City Paper]]|publisher=[[Times-Shamrock Communications]]|date=2005-11-23|accessdate=2011-10-09}} | rev4 = [[BBC Music]] | rev4score = (mixed){{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/music/reviews/r98c|title=Review of Hilary Duff â Most Wanted|last=Kraines|first=Talia|date=2005-11-16|publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation|accessdate=2009-11-02}} | rev5 = [[IGN]] | rev5score = (6.9/10){{cite web|url=http://uk.music.ign.com/articles/642/642502p1.html|title=Hilary Duff â Most Wanted|last=D.|first=Spence|publisher=[[IGN]]. [[News Corporation]]|date=2005-08-17|accessdate=2009-11-02}} | rev6 = [[MTV Southeast Asia|MTV Asia]] | rev6Score = (5/10){{cite web|url=http://web.mtvasia.com/Review/CD/C20050901001286.html|title=Hilary Duff â Most Wanted|last=Leong|first=Gabriel|publisher=[[MTV Southeast Asia|MTV Asia]]. [[MTV Networks Asia Pacific]] (Viacom)|date=2005-09-01 |accessdate=2011-10-15}} | rev7 = ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' | rev7Score = {{Rating|1.5|5}}{{cite news|url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/article-1G1-135173630/reviews-new-pop-blues.html|title=Reviews of New Pop, Blues, Jazz and Classical releases|last=Hiltbrand|first=David|work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]|publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]]|date=2005-08-16|accessdate=2011-10-15}} | rev8 = ''[[The San Francisco Chronicle]]'' | rev8Score = (unfavorable){{cite news|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2005-08-14/entertainment/17386313_1_stooges-and-fun-house-hilary-duff-discs|title=CD Reviews|last=Vaziri|first=Aidin|work=[[The San Francisco Chronicle]]|publisher=[[Hearst Corporation]]|page=2|date=2005-08-14|accessdate=2011-10-09}} | rev9 = [[Slant Magazine]] | rev9score = {{Rating|2|5}}{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/music/review/hilary-duff-most-wanted/613|title=Hilary Duff: Most Wanted|last=Cinquemani|first=Sal|publisher=[[Slant Magazine]]|date=2005-08-15|accessdate=2009-11-02}} }} [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Allmusic]] gave a mixed review of ''Most Wanted'', stating that "hardcore fans will be hard-pressed for a reason to add this to their collection" and that the new songsâ"Wake Up", "Beat of My Heart" and "Break My Heart"â"sound a bit like leftovers". Although he wrote that ''Most Wanted'' "isn't a terrible album by any means, it's not particularly a good one, since Duff's two pop albums [''Metamorphosis'' (2003) and ''Hilary Duff'' (2004)] have distinctive personalities that don't necessarily mesh together [...], and are both more fun than this." Bill Lamb of About.com noted that the three new songs "seem to be marking time instead of finding a new direction" but said that "[the] remaining bulk of this collection is strong." Anthony Miccio, from the ''[[Baltimore City Paper]]'', wrote that the album "doesn't signify the closure of a brief career" but is "meant to satisfy an audience that won't be offended by the opportunity to buy their favorite songs again and again." He noted that Duff's voice was not strong enough and stated that the "rock tracks are surprisingly sluggish." Talia Kraines of [[BBC Music]] commented that " ... there isn't enough here to warrant a purchase if you're already the owner of her back catalogue. But if you're after your first taste of Duff-flavoured pop to listen to in the background as you do your homework, then this album can do no harm." Spence D. of [[IGN]] stated that "the only draw for this album are the three new tracks and the three remixes." He further commented that ''Most Wanted'' is a "filler album" and that "[T]he new songs that are served up still show Duff chasing trends rather than setting them and actively searching for her own voice and image." Sal Cinquemani of [[Slant Magazine]] was critical of the album writing he "literally laughed out loud when I heard the Duffster was releasing a best-of album titled Most Wanted." He praised the Dead Executives produced tracks and concluded the review by writing that "apparently there aren't even enough bearable moments in Duff's recording career to fill one CD". Gabriel Leong of [[MTV Southeast Asia]] started the review by writing "A greatest hits album seems a tad flagrant when you've only had two albums so far. So let's call this one a compilation album instead." Leong noted that the title fitted the album perfectly and that it proves "its innocuous appeal of infectious bubblegum pop." David Hiltbrand of ''[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' commented that it was "a little early in the career" to release a greatest hits album and that it showcased that "Duff is more product than talent." Aidin Vaziri of ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' also commented that it was premature as it was too early in Duff's career to release a greatest hits compilation. He commended the new tracks produced by the Dead Executives writing that they "help alleviate the feeling that this is a total cash grab." In 2006, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' included the album in their Lamest Greatest Hits Albums Ever list.{{cite web|author=Rolling Stone|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/blogs/staff-blog/list-of-the-day-lamest-greatest-hits-albums-ever-20060921|title=List of the Day: Lamest Greatest Hits Albums Ever|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|publisher=[[Jann Wenner|Wenner Media]]|accessdate=2011-10-15}} == Commercial performance == In the United States, ''Most Wanted'' debuted at number one, with sales of over 208,000 units. It became her first album to debut at the top, and her second album to top the chart after ''Metamorphosis'' (2003).{{cite web|url=http://login.vnuemedia.com/bbbiz/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001020095|title=Duff Is 'Most Wanted' On Billboard Album Chart|last=Whitmire|first=Margo|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|date=2005-08-24|accessdate=2011-09-02}} It stayed at the same position in its second week of release, after a 40% drop in sales.{{cite web|url=http://login.vnuemedia.com/bbbiz/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001051422|title=Duff Set Remains 'Most Wanted' At No. 1|last=Whitmire|first=Margo|work=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|date=2005-08-31|accessdate=2011-09-02}} In September 2005, the album was certified [[RIAA certification|platinum]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIIA) for shipments of over one million copies.{{cite web |url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=&artist=Hilary%20Duff&format=&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2010&sort=Artist&perPage=25|title=Gold & Platinum Searchable Database|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|accessdate=2010-01-19}} By January 13, 2007, the album had sold over 1,400,000 copies in the United States.{{cite journal|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=pRIEAAAAMBAJ|title=Disney Stars on the Rise|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|volume=119|issue=2|date=2007-01-13|issn=0006-2510|page=22|accessdate=2011-10-17}} In Canada, the album became Duff's third consecutive album to debut at number one, selling 45,000 units in its initial week.{{cite web|url=http://jam.canoe.ca/Music/Artists/D/Duff_Hilary/2005/08/24/1186328.html|title=Duff is 'Most Wanted' on Canadian charts|first=Martin|last=Kuebler|publisher=[[Jam!]]. [[Canadian Online Explorer]]|date=2005-08-24 |accessdate=2011-09-02}} In December 2005, it was certified two times platinum by the [[Music Canada|Canadian Recording Industry Association]] (CRIA) for shipments of over 200,000 copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.cria.ca/gold/1205_g.php|title=Gold & Platinum â May 2004|publisher=[[Music Canada|Canadian Recording Industry Association]]|accessdate=2011-09-02}} In Australia, the album debuted at number three and was certified platinum by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA) for shipments of over 70,000 copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-2005.htm|title=ARIA Charts â Accreditations â 2005 Albums|publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]]|accessdate=2011-09-02}} In New Zealand, it debuted at number 17 and two weeks later, peaked at number 10 becoming Duff's first and only top 10 entry in New Zealand, to date.{{cite web|url=http://charts.org.nz/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Hilary+Duff|title=Discography Hilary Duff|publisher=charts.org.nz. Hung Medien|accessdate=2011-10-17}} Overseas, in the United Kingdom, ''Most Wanted'' debuted at number 31, with first-week sales of 10,661 copies,{{cite web|url=http://www.musicweek.com/story.asp?sectioncode=1&storycode=16356|title=Westlife pull off chart double|work=[[Music Week]]|publisher=[[UBM plc|United Business Media]]|date=2005-11-07|accessdate=2011-10-15}} and stayed on the chart for a total of five weeks. It was certified [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] by the [[British Phonographic Industry]] (BPI) for shipments of 100,000 copies in January 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certifiedawards/search.aspx|title=Certified Awards Search|publisher=[[British Phonographic Industry]]|accessdate=2011-09-02}} The album peaked at number eight on the [[Irish Albums Chart]] and stayed on the charts for eighteen weeks, with its final appearance on the chart at number sixty-nine.{{cite web|url=http://www.chart-track.co.uk/index.jsp?c=p%2Fmusicvideo%2Fmusic%2Farchive%2Findex_test.jsp&ct=240002&arch=t&lyr=2006&year=2006&week=27|title=Top 75 Artist Album|publisher=GfK [[Chart-Track]]|publisher=[[Irish Recorded Music Association]]|accessdate=2011-10-17}} It was certified gold by the [[Irish Recorded Music Association]] (IRMA) denoting sales/shipments of 7,500 copies. In Japan, the album debuted at number three on the [[Oricon]] charts, with sales of 38892 units.{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/search/result.php?kbn=ja&types=rnk&year=2005&month=8&week=4&submit5.x=20&submit5.y=15|title=æ¤ç´¢çµæ-ORICON STYLE ã¢ã¼ãã£ã¹ã/CDæ¤ç´¢|publisher=[[Oricon]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=2011-10-15}} It stayed on the chart for fourteen weeks and was certified gold by the [[Recording Industry Association of Japan]] (RIAJ). ''Most Wanted'' also peaked within the top 10 in Italy and Ireland, and the top fifty in Mexico and Spain. Due to its appearance on many European charts, it peaked at number 59 on the [[European Top 100 Albums|European Albums Chart]], as compiled by ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]''{{'}}s ''Music & Media''. ==Promotion== ===Singles=== {{Listen | filename = Hilary Duff - Wake_Up.ogg | title = "Wake Up" | description = A 21-second sample of "Wake Up"{{'}}s chorus reflecting the "party anthem" lyrics. Duff sings about having fun. | format = [[Ogg]] }} "Wake Up" was released as the lead single from the compilation. It was serviced to US [[Contemporary hit radio|mainstream radio]] on July 12, 2005,{{cite web|url=http://www.fmqb.com/Article.asp?id=69239#2007 |title=CHR: Available for Airplay|work=[[Friday Morning Quarterback]]|accessdate=2011-09-02}} and was physically released on August 26, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/wake-up-cd-1-r884593|title=Wake Up [CD] â Hilary Duff|publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2011-09-02}} The song was met with generally mixed reviews from critics; a few noted that the Madden-produced track was a standout on the album. Chuck Taylor of ''Billboard'' called the song "an easy ace" and deemed it "a summer beach staple". He also commended Duff's vocal style in the song and remarked that it would "put her singing career on par with her hyperactive acting endeavors."{{cite journal|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uRQEAAAAMBAJ|title=Reviews Spotlight: Singles|last=Taylor|first=Chuck|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc|page=62|volume=117|issue=29|date=2005-07-16|issn=0006-2510|accessdate=2011-10-17}} Stephen Thomas Erlwine of Allmusic commented that it sounded like "leftovers" Commercially, "Wake Up" peaked within the top 10 in Italy, Ireland, Norway, Spain and the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Hilary+Duff&titel=Wake+Up&cat=s|title=Hilary Duff â Wake Up|publisher=australian-charts.com. Hung Medien|accessdate=2011-10-17}} In the United States, the song reached number 29 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, becoming Duff's highest peak at the time.{{cite web|url=http://login.vnuemedia.com/bbbiz/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001021637|title=Chart Beat|work=Billboard|publisher=Prometheus Global Media|date=2005-09-25|accessdate=2011-10-26}}{{cite web|url=http://allmusic.com/album/most-wanted-r782736/charts-awards/billboard-single|title=Most Wanted â Hilary Duff > Charts & Awards > Singles|publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2011-10-26}} The accompanying music video for the song, directed by [[Marc Webb]], portrays Duff in several different looks, representing styles from [[Tokyo]], [[London]], [[Paris]] and [[New York City]]. "Beat of My Heart" was released as the second single from ''Most Wanted'' on December 12, 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/beat-of-my-heart-r970230|title=Beat of My Heart â Hilary Duff|publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|accessdate=2011-09-02}} The song received generally negative reviews from critics, who labelled it repetitive. Chuck Taylor of ''Billboard'' wrote: "Pop music is always appreciated, but this is a kiddie anthem, plain and simple, so repetitive and childlike [...] that is hardly a contender for contemporary radio." The song failed to chart in the US, but was a moderate success elsewhere, peaking within the top 10 in Italy, and the top-twenty in Australia and Spain.{{cite web|url=http://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Hilary+Duff&titel=Beat+Of+My+Heart&cat=s|title=Hilary Duff â Beat Of My Heart|publisher=australian-charts.com. Hung Medien|accessdate=2011-10-17}} The song's accompanying music video, directed by [[Phil Harder]], was influenced by the [[James Bond (film series)#Title sequence|opening title sequences of James Bond films]], and Duff sports different looks inspired by the different eras of the Bond films.{{cite web|last=Vineyard|first=Jennifer |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1510304/hilary-duff-evokes-bond-girls-latest-video.jhtml |title=Hilary Duff Forms a Bond with Espionage Hotties in New Video|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks (Viacom)|date=2005-09-24|accessdate=2011-09-02}} In a few European countries, "Fly" was released as the second single from ''Most Wanted'' on March 13, 2006.{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B000ECWZXY|title=Fly: Hilary Duff|publisher=Amazon.co.uk|accessdate=2011-10-17}} It charted and peaked at number 20 on the [[UK Singles Chart]] and number 13 on the [[Italian Singles Chart]]. A third single from the album was planned to be released, but due to Duff's busy schedule and exhaustion from touring, it did not materialize.{{cite web|last=Vineyard |first=Jennifer|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1513377/hilary-puts-everything-on-hold-do-nothing.jhtml|title=Hilary Duff Puts Everything on Hold to Do Nothing|publisher=MTV News. MTV Networks (Viacom)|date=2005-11-09|accessdate=2011-09-02}} Instead, "Supergirl" was released as a [[music download|download]]-only single on February 26, 2006.Supergirl digital-only single release details: *{{cite web|url=http://music.napster.com/hilary-duff-music/album/supergirl/13350315|title=Supergirl by Hilary Duff|publisher=[[Napster]]|accessdate=2011-10-17}} *{{cite web|url=http://itunes.apple.com/us/album/supergirl-single/id128473166|title=Supergirl â Single by Hilary Duff|publisher=[[iTunes|iTunes Store]]. [[Apple Inc.|Apple Inc]]|accessdate=2011-10-17}} *{{cite web|url=http://mp3.rhapsody.com/hilary-duff/supergirl|title=Rhapsody MP3 Music Downloads: Supergirl by Hilary Duff|publisher=[[Rhapsody (online music service)|Rhapsody]]|accessdate=2011-10-17}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.amazon.com/dp/B001P7B70Y|title=Supergirl: Hilary Duff|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=2011-10-17}} "Wake Up" and "Supergirl" were also used in an [[Advertising campaign|advertisement campaign]] to promote [[Candie's]]' clothing line for young women in 2005â06.{{cite web|last=Donahue|first=Ann|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2008/06/07/us-panettiere-idINN0737718620080607|title=Panettiere, fashion label team on album|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=2008-06-07|accessdate=2011-10-17}} ===Tour=== To promote the album, Duff embarked on a worldwide [[arena]] tour, before its release. Entitled the Still Most Wanted Tour, the tourâan extension of the [[Hilary Duff concert tours#Most Wanted Tour|Most Wanted Tour]] (2004â05)âbegan on July 12, 2005 in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]] at the [[Greek Theatre (Los Angeles)|Greek Theatre]], with a [[United States]] leg.{{cite web|url=http://top40.about.com/od/concerts/a/hilaryduffc.htm|last=Lamb|first=Bill|title=Hilary Duff Concert Tour|publisher=About.com. The New York Times Company|accessdate=2011-08-17}}{{cite web|author=IGN Music |url=http://music.ign.com/articles/630/630303p1.html|title=Hilary Duff Is Still Most Wanted|publisher=IGN. News Corporation|date=2005-06-30|accessdate=2011-08-17}} Following the end of the US leg in September, it visited [[Australia]] in December. Duff then made her Canadian touring debut in January 2006,{{cite web|url=http://www.channelcanada.com/Article1144.html |title=Hollywood Records / Universal Music Chooses CTV's eTalk Daily as Exclusive Partner for Hilary Duff's Still Most Wanted Tour |publisher=Channel Canada|date=2005-11-22|accessdate=2011-08-31}} before heading off to [[Europe]] in April.{{cite web|url=http://www.shauneybaby.com/html/events.html|title=Events|first=Shauney Sherice|last=Recke|publisher=Shauneybaby.com|accessdate=2011-08-31}} She then visited [[Latin America]], before closing the tour up with various dates in [[North America]] from June to September 2006.{{cite web|url=http://hilaryduff.com/tour|title=Tour|publisher=Hilary Duff. [[Hollywood Records]]|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20060701224307/http://hilaryduff.com/tour |archivedate=2006-07-01|accessdate=2011-08-17}} The set list contained songs from ''Metamorphosis'', ''Hilary Duff''. Duff also premiered "Wake Up", "Beat of My Heart" and "Break My Heart" on the tour.{{cite web|last=Tecson|first=Brandee J.|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1505649/duff-launches-tour-with-gasp-only-one-outfit.jhtml|title=Hilary Duff Launches Tour Amid Sea Of Glow Sticks, In (Gasp!) Only One Outfit|publisher=MTV. MTV Networks (Viacom)|date=2005-07-13|accessdate=2011-10-17}} == Track listing == {{Track listing | headline = Standard edition{{Cite album-notes |title=Most Wanted |artist=[[Hilary Duff]] |year=2005
